subject: Re: [junit] Dependencies between tests and test ordering

messageBody:
--- Maciej Zawadzki <mbz@...> wrote:
> For example, if the testCreate() method created an object, I could
> store a reference to it in an instance attribute and access again
> from the other test methods (testRestore() for example).

I think the reason you're finding this difficult to do is that its
purposefully discouraged by the framework.

The paradigm is that tests *must* be independent. Part of the reason
for this is that if one test fails, you can re-run it during your
debugging to see if you've made progress fixing the problem.

If your tests aren't independent, you'll have to have some way of
documenting which test's side effect allows your other test(s) to be
run.

As you point out, though, there's clearly a cost involved in making all
your tests independent, and use the 'setup() and teardown()' methods.
If this cost is prohibitive, you may want to consider changing those
tests that are currently separate, interrelated tests to be one
independent test. (I'd to this by renaming your current interrelated
test methods to be private helper methods, and have a larger 'test'
method call them in the order you want).

This is the approach I've been taking, and its simplified things a
great deal both in my own process, and when people use tests I've
written.

-Kevin Klinemeier
